headline: US corporate bond dealmaking jumps day after Fed rate cut
summary: (Reuters) -U.S. corporate bond deal-making in the investment-grade market picked up on Thursday following a quiet period earlier in the week, spurred by a quarter basis point rate cut from the Federal Reserve at its September meeting.  At least nine corporate issuers tapped the investment-grade corporate bond market for almost $15 billion in paper on Thursday, according to market participants.  Other major borrowers to tap the U.S. bond market on Thursday included Swiss bank UBS Group and French bank Crédit Agricole.

headline: Is AT&T’s Dividend Sustainable Among the Best Performing in 2025 Dividend Stocks?
summary: AT&T Inc. (NYSE:T) is included among the 15 Best Performing Dividend Stocks So Far in 2025. AT&T Inc. (NYSE:T) has spent years shedding the media and entertainment businesses it once acquired in a failed attempt to become a media conglomerate. With that chapter behind it, the company is now focused squarely on its core operations […]

headline: AT&T Looking to Sell at Least $4 Billion in High-Grade Bonds
summary: The telecommunications company is offering notes in as many as four parts, the people said.  A representative for AT&T confirmed the sale but didn’t specify the size of the issuance.  Bank of America Corp., BNP Paribas SA, Citigroup Inc., JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Mizuho Financial Group are leading Thursday’s bond sale, the people said.

headline: 'Offices Need To Start Feeling A Little Bit More Like Hotels,' Behind One CBRE Exec's Approach To The Future Of In-Person Work
summary: Within the last month, Paramount, Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT), and Novo Nordisk (NYSE:NVO) have announced return-to-office mandates. The companies join other major employers like Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN), AT&T (NYSE:T), and Disney (NYSE:DIS) in requiring that employees work in-person for at least half the week. While the employers say that the increase in face time will allow for more innovation, increase employee engagement, and boost productivity, many workers aren't sold on the idea. Partially, becau

headline: 2 Safe-and-Steady Stocks to Consider Right Now and 1 Facing Headwinds
summary: A stock with low volatility can be reassuring, but it doesn’t always mean strong long-term performance. Investors who prioritize stability may miss out on higher-reward opportunities elsewhere.
